review.title: Disruptive Event Classification using PMU Data in Distribution Networks
review.abstract: Proliferation of advanced metering devices with high sampling rates in distribution grids, e.g., micro-phasor measurement units ({\mu}PMU), provides unprecedented potentials for wide-area monitoring and diagnostic applications, e.g., situational awareness, health monitoring of distribution assets. Unexpected disruptive events interrupting the normal operation of assets in distribution grids can eventually lead to permanent failure with expensive replacement cost over time. Therefore, disruptive event classification provides useful information for preventive maintenance of the assets in distribution networks. Preventive maintenance provides wide range of benefits in terms of time, avoiding unexpected outages, maintenance crew utilization, and equipment replacement cost. In this paper, a PMU-data-driven framework is proposed for classification of disruptive events in distribution networks. The two disruptive events, i.e., malfunctioned capacitor bank switching and malfunctioned regulator on-load tap changer (OLTC) switching are considered and distinguished from the normal abrupt load change in distribution grids. The performance of the proposed framework is verified using the simulation of the events in the IEEE 13-bus distribution network. The event classification is formulated using two different algorithms as; i) principle component analysis (PCA) together with multi-class support vector machine (SVM), and ii) autoencoder along with softmax classifier. The results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed algorithms and satisfactory classification accuracies.

sections.heading: A. PCA+SVM event classification algorithm
sections.text: The characteristics extracted from PMU data change over time, so that the characteristics are represented by (1) as a characteristic matrix. On the other hand, input into the SVM classifier is a vector and the matrices must be converted into vectors. In this essay, PCA is used to obtain the dominant eigenvalues of the characteristic matrix and is used as input into a multi-class SVM. A summary of PCA and SVM is presented below.

sections.heading: A.1 Principal Component Analysis (PCA)
sections.text: Principal Component Analysis (PCA) is a technique for reducing the dimensionality of the problem and determining the essential characteristics of the systems. In addition, it can be used in pattern recognition in high-dimensional data and has a wide range of applications, e.g. image processing and facerecognition as well as data mining. Further studies can be found under [25].

sections.heading: A.2 Support Vector Machine (SVM)
sections.text: Supported Vector Machine (SVM) is a supervised classification algorithm that uses linear or non-linear hyperplanes to separate classes from each other. The goal is to maximize the distance between the hyperplanes, and therefore the problem is formulated as a limited optimization problem. In addition, SVM can be applied to nonlinear data sets, using a method called Kernel Trick, in which original data is mapped into a higher dimensional space. In this paper, we used the Gaussian Kernel function. Further explanations can be found in [26].Multiple algorithms have been proposed for multi-class classification in the past. In this paper, a one-against-all algorithm is used to classify events relative to all other classes using multiple binary SVMs.

sections.heading: B. Autoencoder+ Softmax event classification algorithm
sections.text: In this method, the new feature matrix is first normalized by the mean and standard deviation of the historical feature matrix. Then, the rows of the normalized feature matrix are stacked one on top of the other to create an input vector. Subsequently, the feature vector is used as input for feature compression of the input vector on the AutoEncoder layer. The Softmax layer is then performed with the compressed vector to classify the events. Fig. 1.b shows the flowchart and the summary is presented below.

sections.heading: B.1 Autoencoder
sections.text: An autoencoder belongs to the family of artificial neural networks and is used as an unattended learning algorithm. It takes the data as input and tries to reconstruct the data through two levels of encoding and decoding.The learning process is carried out using back-propagation algorithms and the goal of the training is to minimize the reconstruction error. An autoencoder takes the data as input and assigns it to 1 (+) (3), where 1, W and b are the elementary sigmoid function, the weight matrix and the bias term respectively. Then it maps to the input to reconstruct the input with = 2 (+) (4), where 2, "and" are the elemental sigmoid function, the weight matrix and the bias term respectively. [27]

metadata.abstractText: Proliferation of advanced metering devices with high sampling rates in distribution grids, e.g., micro-phasor measurement units (μPMU), provides unprecedented potentials for wide-area monitoring and diagnostic applications, e.g., situational awareness, health monitoring of distribution assets. In this paper, a PMUdata-driven framework is proposed for classification of disruptive events in distribution networks. The event classification is formulated using two different algorithms as; i) principle component analysis (PCA) together with multi-class support vector machine (SVM), and ii) autoencoder along with softmax classifier. The results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed algorithms and satisfactory classification accuracies.
